veroku.factors.gaussian module¶

A module for instantiating and performing operations on multivariate Gaussian and Gaussian mixture distributions.

class veroku.factors.gaussian.Gaussian(cov=None, mean=None, log_weight=None, K=None, h=None, g=None, var_names=None)[source]¶

Bases: veroku.factors.factor.Factor

A class for instantiating and performing operations om multivariate Gaussian distributions.

fix_non_psd_matrices()[source]¶
get_K()[source]¶

Get the K matrix (after ensuring that the canonical form is updated.) :return: The K parameter.

get_complex_log_weight()[source]¶

Get the log weight even in cases where the determinant of the covariance matrix is negative. In such cases the log_weight no longer corresponds to the integral and the log of the weight will have a imaginary component. Computing the complex log-weight can however still be useful: it is used, for example, in the (experimental) Gaussian mixture division function (_gm_division_m2).

get_complex_weight()[source]¶

Get (possibly complex) weight parameter. :return: weight parameter

get_cov()[source]¶

Get the covariance matrix (after ensuring that the covariance form is updated.) :return: The cov parameter.

get_g()[source]¶

Get the g scalar (after ensuring that the canonical form is updated.) :return: The g parameter.

get_h()[source]¶

Get the log h vector (after ensuring that the canonical form is updated.) :return: The h parameter.

get_log_weight()[source]¶

Get the log weight (after ensuring that the covariance form is updated.) :return: The log_weight parameter.

get_mean()[source]¶

Get the mean vector (after ensuring that the covariance form is updated.) :return: The mean parameter.

get_weight()[source]¶

Get the weight of the distribution - the value of the integral of the (possibly unnormalised) distribution. :return: the weight

invert()[source]¶

Invert this Gaussian (1/Gaussian). This is used in the approximate Gaussian mixture division algorithms. :return: the inverted Gaussian

property joint_distribution¶
kl_divergence(factor, normalise_factor=True)[source]¶

Get D_KL(self||factor). D_KL(P|Q) = sum(P*log(P/Q)) :param factor: The other factor :return: The Kullback-Leibler divergence

Reference https://infoscience.epfl.ch/record/174055/files/durrieuThiranKelly_kldiv_icassp2012_R1.pdf, page 1.

log_potential(x_val, vrs=None)[source]¶

Get the log of the value of the Gaussian potential at x_. :param x_val: the vector (or vector-like object) to evaluate the GaussianMixture at :return: log of the value of the GaussianMixture potential at x

classmethod make_vacuous(var_names, g=0.0)[source]¶

Make an vacuous Gaussian distribution with a zero precision matrix and zero h vector and zero g value. This ‘Gaussian’ is effectively a constant function (it has infinite variance and infinite mass) with value exp(g) :return: The vacuous Gaussian

marginalise(vrs, keep=False)[source]¶

Integrate out variables from this Gaussian. :param vrs: (list) a subset of variables in the factor’s scope :param keep: Whether to keep or sum out vrs :return: the resulting Gaussian marginal

normalise()[source]¶
observe(vrs, values)[source]¶

Observe a subset of the variables in the scope of this Gaussian and return the resulting factor. :param vrs: the names of the observed variable (list) :param values: the values of the observed variables (list or vector-like object) :return: the resulting Gaussian

plot(log=False, xlim=None, ylim=None)[source]¶

Plot the Gaussian mixture potential function (only for 1d and 2d functions) :param log: if this is True, the log-potential will be plotted :param xlim: the x limits to plot the function over (optional) :param ylim: the y limits to plot the function over (optional and only used in 2d case)

potential(x_val)[source]¶

Get the value of the Gaussian potential at x_. :param x_val: the vector (or vector-like object) to evaluate the Gaussian at :return: the value of the Gaussian potential at x_

sample(num_samples)[source]¶

Draw samples from the Gaussian distribution. :return:

show(update_covform=True, show_canform=False)[source]¶

Print the parameters of the Gaussian distribution

Visualise the parameters with plots.

veroku.factors.gaussian.make_random_gaussian(var_names, mean_range=[- 10, 10], cov_range=[1, 10])[source]¶

Make a d dimensional random Gaussian by independently sampling the mean and covariance parameters from uniform distributions. :param var_names: (string list) The variable name of the factor :param mean_range: (float list) The range between which a mean will the uniformly sampled. :param cov_range: (float list)The range between which a covariance will the uniformly sampled. :return: The random Gaussian object.

veroku.factors.gaussian.make_std_gaussian(var_names)[source]¶

Make a d dimensional standard Gaussian. :param var_names: (string list) The variable name of the factor :return: The standard Gaussian object.

veroku.factors.gaussian.split_gaussian(gaussian)[source]¶

Split a Gaussian into a three component Gaussian Mixture, with different means. :param gaussian: The Gaussian distribution to split. : :return: The split Gaussian Mixture.
